bestBHT.bht: True greatness is not found in vain titles and the pursuit of lordship, but in humble service to others. As Jesus instructed his disciples, they were to act as servants, not seeking greatness in rank or position. The true example of greatness is found in the youngest and most humble disciple, John. Jesus calls his followers to condescend to those of low estate and to esteem each other above themselves. The role of apostles and ministers is not one of domination, but of service to humanity. In establishing a new aristocracy, Jesus redefines greatness as humility and selfless service.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: little avail has this condemnation of "lordship" and vain
titles been against the vanity of Christian ecclesiastics?
Marvin Vincent: Doth serve. See on minister, Matthew 20:26.
Philip Schaff: Luke 22:26. But not so ye. They shall be ‘kings,’ but after a different fashion. The aristocracy our Lord here establishes is one of humility.
Archibald T. Robertson: Become (γινεσθω). Present middle imperative of γινομα. Act so. True greatness is in service, not in rank.
John Gill: let him be as the younger; as John, the beloved disciple, who was the youngest of them; and be as modest, and as humble as he
reckon himself as in his place, and condescend to men of low estates, and esteem each other, even the youngest, better than himself.
the apostles and ministers of the word, though they are over others in the Lord, and have the rule over them, yet they are servants for Jesus' sake, and so ought to reckon themselves
John Wesley: But ye are to be benefactors to mankind, not by governing, but by serving.

bhtAttempts.bht: True greatness is not found in vain titles and the pursuit of lordship, but in humble service to others. As Jesus instructed his disciples, they were to act as servants, not seeking greatness in rank or position. The true example of greatness is found in the youngest and most humble disciple, John. Jesus calls his followers to condescend to those of low estate and to esteem each other above themselves. The role of apostles and ministers is not one of domination, but of service to humanity. In establishing a new aristocracy, Jesus redefines greatness as humility and selfless service.

True greatness lies not in seeking titles or dominion, but in serving others humbly and selflessly. In Luke 22:26, Jesus instructs his disciples to adopt the mindset of the youngest and most humble among them, like John. He calls them to consider themselves in their proper place and to have a lowly attitude, esteeming others as greater than themselves. The apostles and ministers of the word are not to govern but to serve, embodying a new aristocracy founded on humility and benevolence.

True greatness is found in humble service, not in the pursuit of titles and positions. Jesus reminds his disciples to act as servants, emulating the humility of the youngest disciple, John. They are to consider themselves in their proper place and to value others above themselves. The role of the apostles and ministers of the word is not one of ruling, but rather of serving. This new form of aristocracy is based on humility and selflessness, reflecting the true nature of greatness.

True greatness is not attained through seeking titles and positions of power, but through humble service to others. Jesus teaches his disciples to emulate the youngest and most humble disciple, John, by considering themselves in their rightful place and valuing others above themselves. As apostles and ministers of the word, their role is not one of ruling, but of serving. This challenges the concept of traditional aristocracy and establishes a new form of greatness rooted in humility and selflessness.

True greatness is not found in the pursuit of titles and lordship, but in serving others with humility. Jesus instructs his disciples to follow the example of the youngest and most humble disciple, John. By considering themselves in their rightful place and valuing others above themselves, they demonstrate true greatness. This redefines the concept of aristocracy, as it is not based on power and authority, but on selfless service. Apostles and ministers are called to be benefactors to humanity through their humble acts of service.
